title: Tories spent £1,200,000 on negative anti-Jeremy Corbyn social media adverts
text:
Labour’s digital strategy was far more positive (Picture: Getty)

Young people and social media users were bombarded with divisive attack adverts by the Conservatives that appear to have had little impact.

Despite £1.2 million being spent, the Tories failed to win over a majority of young voters.

Care home consultant jailed for not giving evidence at inquest of mentally-ill teenager

The General Election saw huge surges among youth votes for Labour – it is believed 72% of young people voted.

While Theresa May’s Tories relied on expensive targeted adverts, Labour’s social media strategy was far more positive.

The Conservatives filled Facebook, YouTube and Snapchat with adverts aimed at Jeremy Corbyn.

The attacks mostly focused on divisive leadership (Picture: Conservatives/Facebook)

The Labour leader was accused of being a terrorist sympathiser in relentless adverts.

And an anti-Corbyn advert, paid for by the Conservatives, even became to the most-viewed political advert ever in the UK.

Nicky Morgan stands down as an MP

Yet young people overwhelmingly supported Labour despite the social media attacks on Mr Corbyn.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The Tories had used the firm Edmonds Elder just like they did under David Cameron in 2015.

Founders Tom Edmonds and Craig Elder claimed last election that digital campaigning had an impact, according to the Guardian.

They were in marked contrast with Labour’s online efforts (Picture: Conservatives/Facebook)

Yet research shows they targeted far too narrowly.

‘Who Targets Me?’ claimed people in just 205 constituencies saw adverts from the Conservatives.

Which MPs are standing down at the 2019 General Election?

That was less than half the constituencies targeted by Labour.

The cost of the targeted adverts, revealed by the Times, is in contrast with the Labour party.

Mr Corbyn and his team courted social media with a policy-driven campaign.

Theresa May was left with a reduced majority (Picture: Getty)

While organic groups like Grime4Corbyn, online comedians and meme makers cost Labour nothing but were effective.

But it wasn’t just who was sharing it, it was the message they were sharing as well.

First picture of grandfather who died after scaling 270ft chimney

The message of hope over division chimed well with young voters.

Sam Jeffers, co-founder of Who Targets Me?, told the Times: ‘The most obvious advantage Labour had was their focus on getting young people out to vote.

‘If you contact young people with a positive message, you’re telling them that you care. The Tories didn’t do that.’

Corbyn’s relentless positive and policy-driven campaign played well (Picture: Momentum/Facebook)

Corbyn had huge organic share numbers in contrast with his rivals (Picture: PA)

Before the election, Tory experts like Tim Bale of Queen Mary University told BBC Trending that targeted attack ads were a ‘no brainer’.

He said: ‘The Tories know from work done by [campaign strategists] Lynton Crosby and Mark Textor that Corbyn is Labour’s biggest weakness and May is their biggest strength.’

Sir Lynton Crosby, who was knighted following the successful 2015 election, was responsible for the campaign.

Royal Opera House graphic designer killed fiancée in shower

Yet he now faces tough criticism and not just from Britain – but also his native Australia.

The former Prime Minister ‘down under’ has blasted him and doubted Crosby’s election winning ability.

Kevin Rudd said: ‘It seems “Sir” Lynton Crosby, Australian conservative political hatchet man, may not have had such a brilliant British election after all.’
